Authors:
Tzu Ho Chou, Yu Tzean, Guey Yuh Liou, Kuo Fan Yuan, Chun
Neng Wang, Hon Tsen Yu, Shean Shong Tzean
Title:
Phylogeny of Antrodia and allied taxa based on LSU-, SSU-,
and internal transcribed spacer nuclear rDNA sequences
Abstract:
Genus Antrodia is a group of polyporoid that caused brown
root rot on woods, typically on conifers. Some member of Antrodia are
characterized with potent medicinal usage, while the other having
potential application in bioremediation. To solve the nomenclatural
conundrum of Antrodia and allied taxa, phylogenetic study was initiated.
Totally we generate SSU (18S), ITS and LSU (28S) rDNA regions of 44
isolates, including 20 Antrodia species, 5 Antrodiella species and 9
allied polyporoids. Totally, including these 44 isolates and sequences
retrieved from GenBank NCBI, LSU of 161 isolates, 77 genera, 138 species
of polypores were subjected to analysis by maximum parsimony (MP)
method. The overview topology of the phylogram revealed the
heterogeneous, polyphyletic nature of the Antrodia genus, which
comprising at least 8 groups. Further analysis of concatenated sequences
of 18S-5.8S-28S or ITS1-ITS2 , generated from the 34 species, the former
by MP, maximum likelihood (ML), neighbor joining (NJ) and Bayesian
inference (BI), or the latter by BI, further showed the polyphyletic
cladograms, though not all branches gained high bootstrap support. The
heterogeneous nature of the Antrodia were further verified by best
unconstrained trees by Templeton, Winning-site, Kishino Hasegawa, and
Shimodaira Hasegawa tests. Obviously, the current Antrodia complex is
better be divided into several independent genera; recombination of A.
gossypia and Antrodiella lalashana are needed. The polyphyletic Phlebia
genus is distinct and require further revision.
